revision.comment: Typo fixing, replaced: movement movement → movement using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The '''African Social Forum''' is an [[Africa]]n social movement opposed to [[neo-liberal]] economic policies in Africa and what they see as the exploitation of the African continent in a framework of neo-liberal [[globalisation]].http://www.africansocialforum.org/english/charter.htm The idea for the African Social Forum originated at the World Social Forum in [[Porto Alegre]] ([[Brazil]]) from 25 to January 30, 2001, upon the recognition that of the 14,000 representatives, only 50 were from Africa. The first Forum was held in 2002 in [[Bamako, Mali]], with 45 countries represented. The Bamako Declaration approved at the 2002 forum include the following: ''A strong consensus emerged at the Bamako Forum that the values, practices, structures and institutions of the currently dominant neo-liberal order are inimical to and incompatible with the realization of Africa's dignity, values, and aspirations...
The Forum demands of its political leaders that they do not further inflict on Africa the unjust system of the [[Bretton Woods system|Bretton Woods]] institutions in the name of financing Africa's development''.” African Social Forum: The Bamako Declaration, p. 1-2 The motto of the African Social Forum, adopted from the [[World Social Forum|WSF]], is "Another Africa is possible". ==Aims== The aims of the movement as listed on their website are as follows: * To consolidate the capacities of analysis, proposal and mobilization of the organizations of the African social movement so that they can fully play their part in Africa and within the world social movement, * To build an African space of concerted development of alternatives to néo-liberal globalization, starting from a diagnosis of its social, economic and political effects, * To define strategies of social, economic and political rebuilding, including a redefinition of the role of the State, market and organizations citizens, * To define the methods of control citizen so that political alternation supports the expression and the implementation of alternative answers, credible and viable.http://www.africansocialforum.org/english/forum.htm ==References== ==External links== * [http://www.africansocialforum.org/english/forum.htm The African Social Forum official website] [[Category:Politics of Africa]]

{{cleanup|date=January 2018|reason=The article lacks citations regarding the band's history.}}
'''Agapeland''', or "''Land Called Love''," is a fictional place created for a series of children's Christian musical albums by [[Candle (band)|Candle]], [[Birdwing Kid's Korus]], [[Barry McGuire]], Tony Salerno, Jim and Dee Patton, and [[Agape Force]] in the 1970s and 1980s. Many of these have been recently re-released on CD including the multi [[Dove Award]] winning ''[[Music Machine (album series)|Music Machine]]'' & ''[[Bullfrogs and Butterflies]]'' series.
==Musical album releases== * ''[[Agapeland (album)|Agapeland]]'' * ''[[Bullfrogs and Butterflies (album)|Bullfrogs and Butterflies]]'' (a.k.a. ''Bullfrogs and Butterflies: God is My Friend'') (available on CD) * ''[[Bullfrogs and Butterflies II]]'' (a.k.a. ''Bullfrogs and Butterflies II: God Loves Fun'') (available on CD) * ''[[Bullfrogs and Butterflies III]]'' (a.k.a. ''Bullfrogs and Butterflies III: God is Great'') (available on CD) * ''[[Bullfrogs and Butterflies IV]]'' (a.k.a. ''Bullfrogs and Butterflies IV: I've Been Born Again'') (available on CD) * ''[[Music Machine (Candle album)|Music Machine]]'' (a.k.a. ''Music Machine: Fruit of the Spirit'') (available on CD) * ''[[Music Machine II]]'' (a.k.a. ''Music Machine II: All About Love'') (available on CD) * ''[[Music Machine III]]'' (a.k.a. ''Music Machine III: The Majesty of God'') (available on CD) * ''[[Music Machine Club Fun Album]]'' * ''[[Once Upon A Christmas: The Original Story]]'' (featuring Stevie and Nancy from ''[[Music Machine (album series)|Music Machine]]'' and the [[Texas Boys Choir]]) (available on CD) * ''[[Sir Oliver's Song]]'' (available on CD) * ''[[Nathaniel the Grublet]]'' (available on CD) * ''[[Ants'hillvania]]'' (available on CD) * ''[[Ants'hillvania II: The Honeydew Adventure]]'' (available on CD) * ''[[I Am God's Project]]'' * ''[[Animals and Other Things]]'' * ''[[Gingerbrook Fare]]'': ''[[Circus Full of Fun & Learning]]'' * ''[[Gingerbrook Fare]]'': ''[[Three Ring Saturday]]'' * ''[[Agapeland for the Whole Family|Agapeland For The Whole Family - With The National Philharmonic Orchestra of London]]'' * ''[[Agapeland at Play With Holly Heart]]'' * ''[[Adventures in Agapeland]]'' * ''[[The Story of Little Tree]]'' (available on CD) * ''[[The Amazing Book]]'' (available on CD) * ''[[The Amazing Children]]'' (available on CD) * ''[[The Amazing Miracles]]'' (available on CD) * ''[[The Amazing Bible Stories]]'' (available on CD) * ''[[The Birthday Party (Christian album)|The Birthday Party]]'' (available on CD) * ''[[Music From Billabong Tales|Music From Billabong Tales with Uncle Collin and Koala Ted]]'' (available on CD) * ''[[Character Builders]]'' Storybook series (on [[Compact Cassette|cassette]], [[LP album|LP]], [[VHS]], and [[DVD]]) (EPISODES ''Learn More About''...: ''[[Obedience (human behavior)|Obedience]]'', ''[[Self-control|Self Control]]'', ''[[Good and evil|Goodness]]'', ''[[Faith]]'', ''[[Honesty]]'', ''[[Moral responsibility|Responsibility]]'', ''[[Gratitude|Thankfulness]]'', ''[[Gentleness]]'', ''[[Sharing]]'', ''[[Kindness]]'', ''[[Politeness]]'', ''[[Joy]]'', ''[[Confidence]]'', ''[[Love]]'', ''[[Patience]]'', and ''[[Peace]]'')
==Video releases==
* ''[[Billabong Tales]]: The Cranky Crocodile from Curramulka Creek'' * ''Billabong Tales: Creator's Pet'' * ''[[Music Machine (1991 film)|Music Machine]]'' * ''[[Music Machine: Benny's Biggest Battle]]'' * ''Nathaniel the Grublet: The Grublets Learn an Important Lesson about Honesty'' * ''The Amazing Bible Series''

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Norway}} "Alltid sommer" | image = [[File:All_I_Ever_Wanted_(Was_You).jpg|250px]] | caption = | year = 1998 | country = Norway | artist = Lars Fredriksen | as = | with = | language = Norwegian | languages = | composer = David Eriksen | lyricist = Linda Andernach Johansen | conductor = Geir Langslet | place = 8th | points = 79 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1998no from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = San Francisco | prev_link = San Francisco (Tor Endresen song) | next = Living My Life Without You | next_link = Living My Life Without You }} '''"Alltid sommer"''' ("Always Summer", English title: "'''All I Ever Wanted (Was You)'''") was the [[Norway|Norwegian]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1998]], performed in [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] by [[Lars A. Fredriksen|Lars Fredriksen]].
The song is an up-tempo number, with Fredriksen telling his lover what a change she has made in his life. He likens this change to the arrival of a perpetual summer, and tells her that "you won my life".
The song was performed twenty-second on the night, following [[Finland]]'s [[Edea (musical group)|Edea]] with "[[Aava]]" and preceding [[Estonia]]'s [[Koit Toome]] with "[[Mere lapsed]]". At the close of voting, it had received 79 points, placing 8th in a field of 25.
It was succeeded as [[Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest|Norwegian representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1999|1999 Contest]] by [[Stig Van Eijk|Van Eijk]] with "[[Living My Life Without You]]".
{{Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1998}}
[[Category:Eurovision songs of Norway]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1998]] [[Category:1998 songs]] [[Category:Universal Records singles]] [[Category:1998 singles]]
{{norway-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox film | name = Blood Wedding | image = | caption = | director = [[Souheil Ben-Barka]] | producer = | writer = Souheil Ben-Barka
[[Federico García Lorca]] | starring = [[Irene Papas]] | music = | cinematography = Girolamo La Rosa | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|df=yes|1977}} | runtime = 80 minutes | country = Morocco | language = French | budget = }} '''''Blood Wedding''''' ({{lang-fr|'''Noces de sang'''}}) is a 1977 Moroccan [[drama film]] directed by [[Souheil Ben-Barka]].{{cite web |url=http://mubi.com/films/blood-wedding--2 |title=Blood Wedding |accessdate=11 October 2012 |work=mubi |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002022218/http://mubi.com/films/blood-wedding--2 |archivedate=2 October 2012 |df= }} The film was selected as the Moroccan entry for [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[50th Academy Awards]], but was not accepted as a nominee.[[Margaret Herrick Library]], [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]]. The film is based on the [[Blood Wedding|Spanish play]] by [[Federico García Lorca|Federico Garcia Lorca]]. ==Cast== * [[Irene Papas]] as La mère * [[Laurent Terzieff]] as Amrouch * Djamila as La fiancée * Miloud Habachi as Le fiancé * Doghmi Larbi as La père * Muni as La servante * Souad Jalil as La femme d'Amrouch * Naima Lamcharki as La folle * Mohamed El Baz as Le berger * Izza Gennini as La voisine ==See also== * [[List of submissions to the 50th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]] * [[List of Moroccan submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0316328|Blood Wedding}} {{Blood Wedding}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Blood Wedding}} [[Category:1977 films]] [[Category:Moroccan films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:1970s drama films]] {{Morocco-film-stub}}

{{italic title}} The '''''Budapesti Hírlap''''' was a [[Hungary|Hungarian]] daily newspaper published in [[Budapest]] from 16 June 1881 to 1938.<ref name=loc>{{cite web|title=Hungarian Newspapers at the Library of Congress|url=https://www.loc.gov/rr/european/newspapers/hu/hunews.html|work=The Library of Congress|accessdate=26 May 2015}}</ref><ref name="alb">{{cite book|author=Albert Tezla|title=Hungarian Authors; a Bibliographical Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aOK0vb9WwaIC&pg=PA704|accessdate=26 May 2015|date=1 January 1970|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-42650-4|page=704}}</ref> Between 25 March and 28 September 1919 it was temporarily closed down.<ref name=loc/> The paper had a [[conservative]] and nationalistic orientation.<ref name=alb/>
==References== {{Reflist}} * Kútfalvy Oszkár: Újságpaloták. Bp. Akadémiai Kiadó. 1991. * A magyar sajtó története. II/2. kötet. 1867-1892. Szerk. Kosáry Domokos, Németh G. Béla. Bp. 1985. * Dezsényi Béla: A magyar sajtó 250 éve. Bp. 1954-
{{DEFAULTSORT:Budapesti Hirlap}} [[Category:1881 establishments in Hungary]] [[Category:1938 disestablishments in Hungary]] [[Category:Defunct newspapers of Hungary]] [[Category:Hungarian-language newspapers]] [[Category:Media in Budapest]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Budapest]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Hungary]] [[Category:Publications established in 1881]] [[Category:Publications disestablished in 1938]]

{{Infobox newspaper | name = Christian Messenger | logo = Christian_Messenger_logo.jpg | image = | caption = | type = Monthly | format = | founder = [[Basel Mission]] | publisher = Waterville Publishing House | editor = | president = | chiefeditor = | depeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = {{start date and age|1883}} | political = | language = English | ceased publication = | relaunched = | headquarters = | circulation = | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | website = | free = | dirinteractive = | circulation_ref = | school = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | image_size = | image_alt = | motto = | owner = [[Presbyterian Church of Ghana]] | generalmanager = | metroeditor = | metrochief = | publishing_city = [[Accra]] | publishing_country = [[Ghana]] | circulation_date = | readership = | RNI = }}
The '''Christian Messenger''' is an English language monthly publication and the official newspaper of the [[Presbyterian Church of Ghana]].<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://christianmessengerpcg.com/site/about.asp|title=Christian Messenger, Ghana|website=webcache.googleusercontent.com|access-date=2017-12-02|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170522095347/http://christianmessengerpcg.com/site/about.asp|archivedate=2017-05-22|df=}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Survivors_on_the_Gold_Coast.html?id=DvHYAAAAMAAJ|title=Survivors on the Gold Coast: The Basel Missionaries in Colonial Ghana|last=Schweizer|first=Peter Alexander|date=2000|publisher=Smartline Pub.|isbn=9789988600013|language=en}}</ref> It is the oldest, continuously operating faith-based news journal in [[Ghana]], and one of the oldest newspapers in the country.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/history-Christianity-Ghana-Hans-Debrunner/dp/B0006CO3YQ|title=A history of Christianity in Ghana,|last=Debrunner|first=Hans W.|date=1967|publisher=Waterville Pub. House|language=English|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130703222956/http://www.amazon.com/history-Christianity-Ghana-Hans-Debrunner/dp/B0006CO3YQ|archivedate=2013-07-03|df=}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=|title=The Christian Messenger Basel, 1883–1917.|last=The Christian Messenger|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/religion/Christian-Messenger-takes-new-look-163076|title=Christian Messenger takes new look|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-28|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170512024044/http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/religion/Christian-Messenger-takes-new-look-163076|archivedate=2017-05-12|df=}}</ref> It was set up on the [[Gold Coast (British colony)|Gold Coast]] in 1883 by the [[Basel Mission|Basel Evangelical Missionary Society]].<ref name=":2" /> The first issue was published in [[Basel]] on 1 March 1883 under the editorship of the German missionary and philologist, [[Johann Gottlieb Christaller]] who had then retired from the mission.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://dacb.org/stories/ghana/christaller-johannes/|title=Johannes Gottlieb Christaller|last=|first=|date=|website=dacb.org|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180515141005/https://dacb.org/stories/ghana/christaller-johannes/|archive-date=2018-05-15|dead-url=no|access-date=2018-05-15|df=}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://dacb.org/stories/ghana/christaller-j/|title=J. G. Christaller|last=|first=|date=|website=dacb.org|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180406225810/https://dacb.org/stories/ghana/christaller-j/|archive-date=2018-04-06|dead-url=no|access-date=2018-05-15|df=}}</ref>
== History == Christaller noted that many German Basel missionaries were not proficient in the English language and urged prospective writers to make use of English scholars for further review and proofreading before final submission to him, the editor, as he was not a native English speaker.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /> A few months before, in a letter to the editor from Christiansborg dated 13 October 1882, the first Basel missionary-trader Hermann Ludwig Rottman inferred that "t''he primary aim of the journal was to encourage people who were not proficient in English to write in Twi or Ga''"<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /> A similar news publication, t''he Christian Messenger and Examiner'' had earlier been founded in 1859 by Wesleyan missionaries, [[Thomas Birch Freeman]] and Henry Wharton as a medium to translate foreign literature and classical works into native African languages.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" />
Originally, the medium of publication was English, Ga and Twi.<ref name=":6" /> The newspaper temporarily changed its name to the "Christian Reporter" and published solely in Twi while the "Christian Messenger" was printed in Ga.<ref name=":6" /> Subscription climbed to a readership of 600 but sharply decreased over time. After Christaller's death in 1895, the printing of the newspaper ceased. Production started again in 1905 at then newly established Basel Mission Printing Office in Akropong.<ref name=":6" />
The newspaper has opinion pieces, news bulletins, advertisements, [[banns of marriage]] and [[Obituary|obituaries]] and funeral announcements of notable individuals associated with the [[Presbyterian Church of Ghana]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> The newspaper also publishes feature articles on topical issues like ''Fruit of the Spirit'', etc. and publishes authoritative information on the various groups in the Church such as the Women's Fellowship, the Young People's Guild (YPG) and the Young Adult Fellowship (YAF).<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
The administration of the church appoints an [[editor-in-chief]] for a tenure of about four years.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> General oversight and management of the newspaper is carried out by an [[Editorial board|Editorial Board]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> The [[Basel Mission|Basel Missionaries]] originally established the newspaper as a way “''to inform, educate, evangelize and entertain its readers... to the north, east, west and south''” corners of the Church.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> The [[Basel Mission]] under the United Trading Company (UTC) aimed to win over converts to [[Christianity]] through its readership, in addition to provision of Christian activities, general news, entertainment, travel journals as well as relevant political events and on the [[Gold Coast (British colony)|Gold Coast]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /> This was in line with the original aim of the newspaper which was ''"to encourage African scholars to write in Twi and Ga."''<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /> The newspaper also informs readers about the developments within the church, its structure and hierarchy, Presbyterian terminologies as well as the work of the Presbyteries, Districts, Congregations.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> Today, the newspaper also covers socioeconomic, political trends, military history and contemporary changes in global society.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" />
== Notable editors == * [[Johann Gottlieb Christaller]], Basel missionary, translator, linguist and philologist – Editor, 1883 – 1895 * [[Carl Henry Clerk]], Gold Coast educator, administrator, journalist, editor and Presbyterian minister – Editor, 1960 – 1963 * [[Gottlieb Ababio Adom]], Gold Coast educator, journalist, editor and Presbyterian minister – Editor, 1966 – 1970
== References == {{reflist|2}} * [[Category:Newspaper stubs]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Ghana]] {{Ghana-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=October 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox Former Country |native_name = Pulau Pinang (Malay) |conventional_long_name = Penang |common_name = Penang |continent = Asia |region = Southeast Asia |country = Malaya |empire = United Kingdom |status = British Crown Colony
State of the [[Federation of Malaya]] |era = [[Post-war]]{{·}}[[Cold War]] |life_span =1946–1957 |year_start = 1946 |year_end = 1957 |date_start = 1 April |date_end = 31 August |event_start = Dissolution of the Straits Settlements |event_end = Independence as part of the Federation of Malaya |event1 = |date_event1 = |event2 = |date_event2 = |event_post = |date_post = |p1 = Straits Settlements |flag_p1 = Flag of the British Straits Settlements (1874-1942).svg |s1 = Federation of Malaya |flag_s1 = Flag of Malaya.svg |image_flag = Flag of Penang (1946-1949).svg |image_coat = Royal Coat of Arms of the United Kingdom.svg |image_map = MapMalaysiaGeorgeTown.png |image_map_caption = Location of Penang |national_anthem = ''[[God Save the Queen|God Save the King/Queen]]''
[[File:United States Navy Band - God Save the Queen.ogg]] |capital = George Town, Penang |common_languages = [[English language|English]], [[Malay language|Malay]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]] and [[Languages of India|Indian]] languages |government_type = British Crown colony |title_leader = [[List of British monarchs|Monarchs]] |leader1 = [[George VI of the United Kingdom|George VI]] |year_leader1 = 1946–1952 |leader2 = [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Elizabeth II]] |year_leader2 = 1952–1957 |title_representative = Residents-Councillor |representative1 = Sydney Noel King |year_representative1 = 1946–1948 |stat_year1 = |stat_pop1 = |currency = [[Malayan dollar]] |today = {{flag|Malaysia}} |footnotes = }} '''Penang''' was a British [[Crown colony]] from 1946 to 1957. It came under [[United Kingdom|British]] sovereignty after been ceded by the [[Sultanate of Kedah]] in 1786, and had been part of the [[Straits Settlements]] until 1946.{{cite book|author=A. GUTHRIE (of the Straits Settlements, and OTHERS.)|title=The British Possessions in the Straits of Malacca. [An Address to the Secretary of State for the Colonies, Signed by A. Guthrie and Others, and Dated April 20th, 1861, in Reference to the Transfer of the Administration of the British Possessions in the Straits of Malacca to the Colonial Office.]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FUVcAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA1|year=1861|pages=1–}} During [[World War II]], it was occupied by the [[Empire of Japan|Japanese]] from 1942 to 1945. After the post-war dissolution of the Straits Settlements Penang and Malacca become crown colonies in the Federation of Malaya, while [[Post-war Singapore|Singapore]] became a standalone crown colony, separate from Malaya.{{cite web|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/history/events/cf47ce98-0e14-4c1f-a6f7-cb55c99b4df6|title=The Straits Settlements is Dissolved|publisher=National Library Board, Singapore|date=1 April 1946|accessdate=16 July 2016}} In 1955, [[Tunku Abdul Rahman Putra al-Haj|Tunku Abdul Rahman]] held a meeting with the British to discuss the end of British rule in Penang with a merger with [[Malayan Union]] (which was then replaced by [[Federation of Malaya]]). On 31 August 1957, when Malaya achieved its independence from the [[United Kingdom]], Penang was integrated as part of the federation, which later known as [[Malaysia]] when it merged with another territories in [[British Borneo]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nzasia.org.nz/downloads/NZJAS-June09/14_Cheah_3.pdf|title=The Communist Insurgency in Malaysia, 1948–90: Contesting the Nation-State and Social Change|author=Cheah Boon Kheng|work=[[National University of Singapore]]|publisher=[[New Zealand Journal of Asian Studies]]|date=June 2009|accessdate=18 October 2015|page=133/2|format=PDF}} ==References== {{British rule in Malaysian history}} {{British overseas territories}} {{British dependencies governors}} {{Portal bar|British Empire|Malaysia}} {{Coord missing|Malaysia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Penang, Straits Settlement of}} [[Category:History of Penang|Straits Settlement of Penang]] [[Category:British Malaya]] [[Category:Former countries in Malaysian history]] [[Category:Straits Settlements]] {{Malaysia-geo-stub}} {{Asia-hist-stub}}

page.title: Dans le silence, je sens rouler la terre

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = Dans le silence, je sens rouler la terre | image = | caption = | director = [[Mohamed Lakhdar Tati]] | producer = Stella Productions | writer = | starring = | distributor = | released = 2010 | runtime = 52 minutes | country = Algeria
France | language = | budget = | gross = | screenplay = Mohamed Lakhdar Tati | cinematography = Sylvie Petit | editing = Julie Durré | music = Mohamed Zami }} '''''Dans le silence, je sens rouler la terre''''' is a 2010 documentary film. == Synopsis == In 1939, the end of the [[Spanish Civil War]] forced thousands of men, women and children to flee [[Francoist Spain]]. The French administration in [[Algeria]] opened refugee camps to take them in. Seventy years later, a young Algerian investigates the past. Despite the absence of archives and files, the traces of these camps have survived the collective oblivion and still appear in current Algeria. == References == {{RefFCAT|833}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1806864}} [[Category:2010 films]] [[Category:Creative Commons-licensed documentary films]] [[Category:Algerian documentary films]] [[Category:French documentary films]] [[Category:2010s documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about the Spanish Civil War]] [[Category:Documentary films about refugees]] [[Category:Documentary films about African politics]] [[Category:Algerian films]] [[Category:French films]] {{Algeria-film-stub}} {{France-documentary-film-stub}}

[[File:Ecef.png|thumb|upright=1.35|ECEF coordinates in relation to [[latitude]] and [[longitude]]]]
'''ECEF''' (acronym for ''earth-centered, earth-fixed''), also known as '''ECR''' (initialism for ''earth-centered rotational''), is a [[geographic coordinate system|geographic]] and [[Cartesian coordinate system]] and is sometimes known as a "conventional terrestrial" system.<ref>{{cite book |first=Alfred |last=Leick |year=2004 |title=GPS Satellite Surveying |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]]}}</ref> It represents positions as X, Y, and Z coordinates. The point (0, 0, 0) is defined as the [[center of mass]] of [[Earth]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Earth Coordinates |first=James R. |last=Clynch |date=February 2006 |url=http://www.gmat.unsw.edu.au/snap/gps/clynch_pdfs/coorddef.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418092513/http://www.sage.unsw.edu.au/snap/gps/clynch_pdfs/coorddef.pdf |archive-date=2015-04-18}}</ref> hence the term '''geocentric coordinates'''.
Its axes are aligned with the [[international reference pole]] (IRP) and [[IERS Reference Meridian|international reference meridian]] (IRM) that are fixed with respect to Earth's surface,<ref name=ReferenceFrames>{{cite web |url=http://www.weblab.dlr.de/rbrt/pdf/TN_0001.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718231431/http://www.weblab.dlr.de/rbrt/pdf/TN_0001.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-18 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://metadata.dod.mil/mdr/ns/GSIP/crs/WGS84C_3D |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718215214/http://metadata.dod.mil/mdr/ns/GSIP/crs/WGS84C_3D |archivedate=2011-07-18 |df= }}</ref> hence the descriptor ''earth-fixed''. This term can cause confusion, since Earth does not [[Earth's rotation|rotate]] about the z-axis (unlike an inertial system such as [[earth-centered inertial|ECI]]), and is therefore alternatively called ECR.
The z-axis extends through [[true north]], which does not coincide with the instantaneous Earth rotational axis.<ref name=ReferenceFrames/> The slight "wobbling" of the rotational axis is known as [[polar motion]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iers.org/nn_10398/IERS/EN/Science/EarthRotation/PolarMotion.html?__nnn=true |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613193953/http://www.iers.org/nn_10398/IERS/EN/Science/EarthRotation/PolarMotion.html?__nnn=true |archivedate=2011-06-13}}</ref> The x-axis intersects the sphere of the earth at 0° [[latitude]] ([[the equator]]) and 0° [[longitude]] ([[prime meridian]] in Greenwich). This means that ECEF rotates with the earth, and therefore coordinates of a point fixed on the surface of the earth do not change. Conversion from a [[WGS84]] datum to ECEF can be used as an intermediate step in converting velocities to the [[north east down]] coordinate system.
Conversions between ECEF and geodetic coordinates (latitude and longitude) are discussed at [[geographic coordinate conversion]].
==In astronomy== Geocentric coordinates can be used for locating [[astronomical object]]s in the [[Solar System]] in [[three-dimensional space|three dimensions]] along the [[Cartesian coordinate system|Cartesian X, Y, and Z axes]]. They are differentiated from [[topocentric coordinates]], which use the observer's location as the reference point for bearings in [[altitude]] and [[azimuth]]. However, neither system takes Earth's constant motion into account, which requires the addition of a [[time]] component to [[position fixing|fix]] objects.
For [[nearby stars]], astronomers use [[heliocentrism|heliocentric]] coordinates, with the center of the [[Sun]] as the origin. The [[plane of reference]] can be aligned with the Earth's [[celestial equator]], the [[ecliptic]], or the [[Milky Way]]'s [[galactic equator]]. These 3D [[celestial coordinate system]]s add actual distance as the Z axis to the [[equatorial coordinate system|equatorial]], [[ecliptic coordinate system|ecliptic]], and [[galactic coordinate system]]s used in [[spherical astronomy]].
The distances involved are so great compared to the relative velocities of the stars, that for most purposes, the time component can be neglected.
==See also== * [[Geodetic system]] * [[Earth-centered inertial]] coordinate system * [[International Terrestrial Reference System]] (ITRS) * [[Orbital state vectors]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.satsleuth.com/GPS_ECEF_Datum_transformation.htm ECEF datum transformation] Notes on converting ECEF coordinates to WGS-84 datum * [http://www.microem.ru/pages/u_blox/tech/dataconvert/GPS.G1-X-00006.pdf Datum Transformations of GPS Positions Application Note] Clearer notes on converting ECEF coordinates to WGS-84 datum * [http://www.colorado.edu/geography/gcraft/notes/datum/datum.html geodetic datum overview] orientation of the coordinate system and additional information * [https://geographiclib.sourceforge.io GeographicLib] includes a utility CartConvert which converts between [[geodetic system|geodetic]] and geocentric (ECEF) or local Cartesian (ENU) coordinates. This provides accurate results for all inputs including points close to the center of the earth. * [http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/wgs-84-2/ EPSG:4978]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ecef}} [[Category:Global Positioning System]]

revision.text:
{{Other uses|Ecosystem collapse|Collapse (disambiguation){{!}}Collapse}}
{{short description|A situation where an ecosystem suffers a drastic, possibly permanent, reduction in carrying capacity for all organisms}} '''Ecological collapse''' refers to a situation where an [[ecosystem]] suffers a drastic, possibly permanent, reduction in [[carrying capacity]] for all organisms, often resulting in [[mass extinction]]. Usually, an ecological collapse is precipitated by a disastrous event occurring on a short time scale. Ecological collapse can be considered as a consequence of [[ecosystem collapse]] on the biotic elements that depended on the original ecosystem.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Sato |first1=Chloe F. |last2=Lindenmayer |first2=David B. |title=Meeting the Global Ecosystem Collapse Challenge |journal=Conservation Letters |date=2018 |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=e12348 |doi=10.1111/conl.12348 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bland |first1=L. |last2=Rowland |first2=J. |last3=Regan |first3=T. |last4=Keith |first4=D. |last5=Murray |first5=N. |last6=Lester |first6=R. |last7=Linn |first7=M. |last8=Rodríguez |first8=J.P. |last9=Nicholson |first9=E. |title=Developing a standarized definition of ecosystem collapse for risk assessment |journal=Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment |date=2018 |volume=16 |issue=1 |pages=29–36 |doi=10.1002/fee.1747 }}</ref>
Ecosystems have the ability to rebound from a disruptive agent. The difference between collapse or a gentle rebound is determined by two factors—the toxicity of the introduced element and the [[ecological resilience|resiliency of the original ecosystem]].<ref name="Basic Civil Engineering">{{cite book|last1=Gopi|title=Basic Civil Engineering|date=2010|publisher=Pearson Education|location=India|accessdate=2015-10-22}}</ref>
Through natural selection the planet's species have continuously adapted to change through variation in their biological composition and distribution. Mathematically it can be demonstrated that greater numbers of different biological factors tend to dampen fluctuations in each of the individual factors.<ref name="Basic Civil Engineering"/>
Scientists can predict tipping points for ecological collapse. The most frequently used model for predicting [[food web]] collapse is called R50, which is a reliable measurement model for food web robustness.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The reliability of R50 as a measure of vulnerability of food webs to sequential species deletions|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/oik.01588/abstract|journal = Oikos|date = 2015-04-01|issn = 1600-0706|pages = 446–457|volume = 124|issue = 4|doi = 10.1111/oik.01588|first = Tomas|last = Jonsson|first2 = Sofia|last2 = Berg|first3 = Alexander|last3 = Pimenov|first4 = Catherine|last4 = Palmer|first5 = Mark|last5 = Emmerson}}</ref>
==Causes and examples== Although, there is no single cause for ecological collapse, attributing factors include [[asteroid impact]]s, [[Large igneous province|extremely large volcanic eruptions]], and [[abrupt climate change]]. The snowball effect of these attributing factors and ecological collapse are demonstrated within the [[fossil record]]. [[Prehistoric]] examples include the [[Carboniferous Rainforest Collapse]], the [[Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event]], the [[Permian–Triassic extinction event]], and other [[mass extinctions]]. For example, effects of [[climate change]] as a contributing factor towards ecological collapse are demonstrated in the [[Ordovician–Silurian extinction events]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = BBC Nature|url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/extinction_events/Ordovician-Silurian_extinction_event|accessdate = 2015-10-29}}</ref> A possible cause of the Ordovician Extinction was global cooling which affected the habitats of marine life. Consequently, sea creatures such as trilobites, brachiopods, and graptolites became extinct.<ref>{{Cite web|title = BBC Nature|url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/extinction_events/Ordovician%25E2%2580%2593Silurian_extinction_event|accessdate = 2015-10-29}}</ref> Furthermore, Karabonov and colleagues conducted a study to show how during the [[Last Glacial Maximum]] (LGM), alternations in the environment and climate led to ecological collapse in [[Lake Baikal]] and [[Lake Hovsgol]] which then led to species evolution in these systems.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Ecological collapse of Lake Baikal and Lake Hovsgol ecosystems during the Last Glacial and consequences for aquatic species diversity|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0031018204001099|journal = Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology|date = 2004-07-06|pages = 227–243|volume = 209|series = High Latitude Eurasian Palaeoenvironments|issue = 1–4|doi = 10.1016/j.palaeo.2004.02.017|first = Eugene|last = Karabanov|first2 = Douglas|last2 = Williams|first3 = Mikhail|last3 = Kuzmin|first4 = Valentina|last4 = Sideleva|first5 = Galina|last5 = Khursevich|first6 = Alexander|last6 = Prokopenko|first7 = Emilia|last7 = Solotchina|first8 = Lilia|last8 = Tkachenko|first9 = Svetlana|last9 = Fedenya}}</ref> The collapse of Hovsgol's ecosystem during the LGM brought forth a new ecosystem, with limited biodiversity in species and low levels of [[endemism]], in Hovsgol during the Holocene. Karabonov's study also shows that ecological collapse during LGM in Lake Hovsgol led to higher levels of diversity and higher levels of endemism as a byproduct of evolution following the ecological collapse of the LGM. The Ordovician Extinction event and Lake Baikal and Hovsgol demonstrate two effects of ecological collapse on prehistoric environments.
Historic examples include the [[collapse of the Atlantic northwest cod fishery|collapse of the Grand Banks cod]] in the early 1990s, attributed to [[overfishing]].
Important pressures contributing to current and future ecological collapse include [[habitat loss]], [[habitat degradation|degradation]], and [[habitat fragmentation|fragmentation]], overgrazing, [[overexploitation]] of ecosystems by humans, human industrial growth and overpopulation,<ref>{{Cite web|title = On Overpopulation and Ecosystem Collapse {{!}} EcoInternet - Earth Blog|url = http://ecointernet.org/2014/05/17/on-overpopulation-and-ecosystem-collapse/|accessdate = 2015-10-30}}</ref> [[climate change]],[[ocean acidification]], [[pollution]], and [[invasive species]].<ref>{{cite web| title=Living Planet Report|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|url=http://wwf.panda.org/about_our_earth/all_publications/living_planet_report/}}</ref>
==Rainforest collapse== Rainforest collapse refers to the actual past and theoretical future ecological collapse of [[rainforest]]s. It may involve [[habitat fragmentation]] to the point where little rainforest [[biome]] is left, and rainforest species only survive in isolated refugia. Habitat fragmentation can be caused by roads. When humans start to cut down the trees for logging, secondary roads are created that will go unused after its primary use. Once abandoned, the plants of the rainforest will find it difficult to grow back in that area.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Legacy of logging roads in the Congo Basin: How persistent are the scars in forest cover?|url = http://www.esajournals.org/doi/full/10.1890/ES14-00488.1|journal = Ecosphere|date = 2015-04-01|issn = 2150-8925|pages = art64|volume = 6|issue = 4|doi = 10.1890/ES14-00488.1|first = Fritz|last = Kleinschroth|first2 = Sylvie|last2 = Gourlet-Fleury|first3 = Plinio|last3 = Sist|first4 = Fréderic|last4 = Mortier|first5 = John R.|last5 = Healey}}</ref> Forest fragmentation also opens the path for illegal hunting. Species have a hard time finding a new place to settle in these fragments causing ecological collapse. This leads to extinction of many animals in the rainforest.
=== Carboniferous period === {{Main article|Carboniferous rainforest collapse}}
In the [[Carboniferous]] period, [[coal forest]]s, great [[tropical wetland]]s, extended over much of Euramerica (Europe and America). This land supported towering [[lycopsid]]s which fragmented and collapsed abruptly.<ref name="SahneyBentonFerry2010RainforestCollapse">{{ cite journal | url=http://geology.geoscienceworld.org/cgi/content/abstract/38/12/1079 | author= Sahney, S., Benton, M.J. & Falcon-Lang, H.J. | year=2010 | title= Rainforest collapse triggered Pennsylvanian tetrapod diversification in Euramerica | journal=Geology | volume = 38 | pages = 1079–1082 | format=PDF | doi=10.1130/G31182.1 | issue=12}}</ref> The collapse of the rainforests during the [[Carboniferous]] has been attributed to [[Carboniferous rainforest collapse#Possible causes|multiple causes]], including [[climate change]].<ref>{{ cite journal |author1=Fielding, C.R. |author2=Frank, T.D. |author3=Birgenheier, L.P. |author4=Rygel, M.C. |author5=Jones, A.T. |author6=and Roberts, J. | year=2008 | title=Stratigraphic imprint of the Late Palaeozoic Ice Age in eastern Australia: A record of alternating glacial and nonglacial climate regime | journal=Geological Society of London Journal | volume = 165| pages = 129–140 | doi=10.1144/0016-76492007-036}}</ref> Specifically, at this time climate became cooler and drier, conditions that are not favourable to the growth of rainforests and much of the biodiversity within them. This sudden collapse affected several large groups including lycopsids and amphibians. Reptiles prospered in the new environment due to adaptations that let them thrive in drier conditions.<ref name="SahneyBentonFerry2010RainforestCollapse"/>
[[File:Amazonie deforestation.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Fishbone pattern of rainforest fragmentation]]
== Today == A classic pattern of [[forest fragmentation]] is occurring in many [[rainforest]]s including those of the [[Amazon basin|Amazon]], specifically a 'fishbone' pattern formed by the development of roads into the forest. This is of great concern, not only because of the loss of a [[biome]] with many untapped resources and wholesale death of living organisms, but also because plant and animal species extinction is known to correlate with habitat fragmentation.<ref name = Rosenzweig>{{cite book | last = Rosenzweig | first = Michael L. | authorlink = Michael Rosenzweig | title = Species diversity in space & time | year = 1995 | publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] | location = Cambridge, United Kingdom}}</ref>
[[Overgrazing]] was found to cause [[land degradation]], specifically in Southern Europe, which is another driver of ecological collapse and natural landscape loss. Proper management of pastoral landscapes can mitigate risk of desertification.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Exploring the Impact of Overgrazing on Soil Erosion and Land Degradation in a Dry Mediterranean Agro-Forest Landscape (Crete, Greece)|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/15324982.2014.968691|journal = Arid Land Research and Management|date = 2015-07-03|issn = 1532-4982|pages = 360–374|volume = 29|issue = 3|doi = 10.1080/15324982.2014.968691|first = Orestis|last = Kairis|first2 = Christos|last2 = Karavitis|first3 = Luca|last3 = Salvati|first4 = Aikaterini|last4 = Kounalaki|first5 = Kostas|last5 = Kosmas}}</ref>
In 2010 roughly 170 million gallons of oil was dumped into the Gulf of Mexico when BP's Deepwater Horizon oil rig exploded. The effects of the BP oil spill are still being felt today, more than 8,000 marine birds, sea turtles and marine mammals were found dead or injured within months of the clean up effort. The impact of this disaster has unbalanced the food web of the environment. The oil spill occurred at the height of breeding season and as result affected egg and larval animals to the worst extent wiping entire age classes. This loss of a generation down the line will prove dire for future predators of the ecosystem.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.nwf.org/What-We-Do/Protect-Habitat/Gulf-Restoration/Oil-Spill/Effects-on-Wildlife.aspx|title = How Does the BP Oil Spill Impact Wildlife and Habitat?|date = 2015-10-28|accessdate = 2015-10-28|website = National Wildlife Federation|publisher = }}</ref>
In addition, a major concern for marine biologists is the effects of ecological collapse on the coral reefs (who based on fossil evidence are more vulnerable to extinction but also demonstrate greater resilience<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = The future of coral reefs|url = http://www.pnas.org/content/98/10/5419|journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|date = 2001-05-08|issn = 0027-8424|pmc = 33228|pmid = 11344288|pages = 5419–5425|volume = 98|issue = 10|doi = 10.1073/pnas.091092998|first = Nancy|last = Knowlton}}</ref>). An effect of global climate change is the rising sea levels which can lead to reef drowing or [[coral bleaching]].<ref name=":0" /> Human activity, such as fishing, mining, deforestation, etc., serves as a threat for coral reefs by affecting the niche of the coral reefs. For example, Edinger and colleagues<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Reef degradation and coral biodiversity in indonesia: Effects of land-based pollution, destructive fishing practices and changes over time|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0025326X98000472|journal = Marine Pollution Bulletin|date = 1998-08-01|pages = 617–630|volume = 36|issue = 8|doi = 10.1016/S0025-326X(98)00047-2|first = Evan N|last = Edinger|first2 = Jamaluddin|last2 = Jompa|first3 = Gino V|last3 = Limmon|first4 = Wisnu|last4 = Widjatmoko|first5 = Michael J|last5 = Risk}}</ref> demonstrate a correlation between a loss in diversity of coral reefs by 30-60% and human activity such as sewage and/or industrial pollution.
The ocean is in great danger of collapse. In a study of 154 different marine fish species, David Byler found out that many factors such as overfishing, climate change, and fast growth of fish populations will cause ecosystem collapse.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Fishing, fast growth and climate variability increase the risk of collapse|url = http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/282/1813/20151053|journal = Proc. R. Soc. B|date = 2015-08-22|issn = 0962-8452|pmid = 26246548|pages = 20151053|volume = 282|issue = 1813|doi = 10.1098/rspb.2015.1053|first = Malin L.|last = Pinsky|first2 = David|last2 = Byler|pmc=4632620}}</ref> When humans fish, they usually will fish the populations of the higher trophic levels such as salmon and tuna. The depletion of these trophic levels allow the lower trophic level to overpopulate, or populate very rapidly. For example, when the population of catfish is depleting due to overfishing, plankton will then overpopulate because their natural predator is being killed off. This causes an issue called eutrophication. Since the population all consumes oxygen the dissolved oxygen(DO) levels will plummet. The DO levels dropping will cause all the species in that area to have to leave, or they will suffocate. This along with climate change, and ocean acidification can cause the collapse of an ecosystem.
Although global climate change and human dominance are inevitable, humans can institute greater self-awareness in order to aid the habits of creatures such as coral reefs.
Some scientists predict that a global ecological collapse will occur after 50% of the natural landscape is gone due to human development.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Scientists Fear Global Ecological Collapse Once 50% of the Natural Landscape is Gone|url = http://www.treehugger.com/natural-sciences/scientists-fear-global-ecological-collapse-once-50-natural-landscape-gone.html|website = TreeHugger|accessdate = 2015-10-29}}</ref>
== Consequences == Although the causes of ecological collapse are due to factors unique to their environment, they all for the most part share similar ramifications such as loss in biodiversity, trophic cascades, and even extinction. For example, the urbanization and deforestation of the South east Asian Pacific has led to the extinction of three plant species and eight animal species in 2003.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sodhi, Koh, Brook, Ng|first1=Navjot, Lian, Barry, Peter|title=Southeast Asian Biodiversity and impending disaster|journal=Trends in Ecology and Evolution|date=December 2004|volume=19|issue=12|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2004.09.006|pages=654–660}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Arctic shrinkage]] * [[Ecological resilience]] * [[Ecosystem collapse]] * [[Environmental degradation]] * [[Global catastrophic risks#Ecological disaster|Global catastrophic risks § Ecological disaster]] * [[Overshoot (ecology)]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{for|the national Lutheran church of Finland|Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland}} {{Infobox Christian denomination |name = Finnish Evangelical Lutheran Church of America |image = Old Main Suomi College Hancock MI 2009.jpg |imagewidth = |caption = Old Main at the FELC's Suomi College in Hancock, Michigan |main_classification = [[Protestant]] |orientation = [[Lutheran]] |theology = |structure = |leader = |headquarters = [[Calumet, Michigan]] |founder = |founded_date = March 25, 1890 |founded_place = [[Calumet, Michigan]] |parent = [[Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland]] |merged_into = [[Lutheran Church in America]] (1962) |associations = |area = Michigan and other states |congregations = 153 (1961) |members = 36,274 (1961) |other_names = Suomi Synod |ministers = 105 (1961) |tertiary = [[Finlandia University|Suomi College and Theological Seminary]] |publications = |footnotes = }} {{lutheranism}} The '''Finnish Evangelical Lutheran Church of America''' (commonly known as the '''Suomi Synod''') was a Lutheran church body which existed in the United States from 1890 until 1962.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.everyculture.com/multi/Du-Ha/Finnish-Americans.html|title= Finnish Americans|publisher= Advameg, Inc.|author= Marianne Wargelin |accessdate= April 15, 2016}}</ref>
==History== The Finnish Evangelical Lutheran Church of America (FELC) was organized at [[Calumet, Michigan]] in 1890. FELC was defined more by its [[Ethnic Finn|Finnish]] ethnic origin than by any specific theological strain. In 1896, the church established Suomi College and Theological Seminary (now called [[Finlandia University]]) in [[Hancock, Michigan]]. It is the only private institution of higher learning in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula and the only remaining university in North America founded by Finnish immigrants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.finlandia.edu/our-finnish-founders-history-and-heritage.html|title = Suomi College Finnish Heritage|publisher = Finlandia University|accessdate= April 15, 2016}}</ref>
FELC was one of the [[Lutheranism|Lutheran]] church bodies that merged into the [[Lutheran Church in America]] (LCA) in 1962. At that time, FELC had 36,274 members and 105 ministers in 153 congregations, and was the smallest of LCA's founding church bodies.<ref name=ARDA>{{cite web|title=Finnish Evangelical Lutheran Church (Suomi Synod)|url=http://www.thearda.com/Denoms/D_903.asp|work=American Denomination Profiles|publisher=[[Association of Religion Data Archives]]|accessdate=August 27, 2016}}</ref> The LCA was subsequently party to the merger that created the [[Evangelical Lutheran Church in America]] in 1988.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://cyclopedia.lcms.org/display.asp?t1=f&word=FINNISHLUTHERANSINAMERICA|title= Finnish Lutherans in America.|publisher= Concordia Publishing House|accessdate= April 15, 2016}}</ref>
==Presidents== *Juho K. Nikander (1890–1898)<ref>{{cite web|url= http://cyclopedia.lcms.org/display.asp?t1=n&word=NI|title= Nikander, Juho Kustaa|publisher= Concordia Publishing House|accessdate= April 15, 2016}}</ref> *Kaarle Leonard Tolonen (1898–1902) <ref>Holmio, Armas Kustaa Ensio (2001) ''History of the Finns in Michigan'' (Wayne State University , page 188) {{ISBN|9780814329740}}</ref> *Juho K. Nikander (1902–1919) *John Wargelin (1919–1919) *Alvar Albert Rautalahti (1919–1922) *Alfred Haapanen (1922–1950) *John Wargelin (1950–1955)<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.kansallisbiografia.fi/kb/artikkeli/4398/ |title = Wargelin, John (1881 - 1970)|publisher = Biografiakeskus|accessdate= April 15, 2016}}</ref> *Raymond Waldemar Wargelin (1955–1962)<ref>{{cite web|url= http://archives.ihrc.umn.edu/vitrage/all/wa/ihrc2819.html|title= Wargelin, Raymond Waldemar, Papers |publisher= College of Liberal Arts, University of Minnesota|accessdate= April 15, 2016}}</ref> ==See also== *[[National Evangelical Lutheran Church]] *[[Apostolic Lutheran Church of America]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==Other sources== * Wolf, Edmund Jacob (1889) ''The Lutherans in America; a story of struggle, progress, influence and marvelous growth'' (New York: J.A. Hill) * Bente, F. (1919) ''American Lutheranism Volume II'' (St. Louis: Concordia Publishing House) * Nichol, Todd W. (1986) All ''These Lutherans'' (Minneapolis: Augsburg Publishers)
==External links== *Haapanen, Alfred (1949) [http://www.genealogia.fi/emi/art/article369e.htm ''Our Church. Suomi Synod. The Finnish Evangelical Lutheran Church of America''] (Hancock, Michigan: Finnish Lutheran Book Concern)
[[Category:Evangelical Lutheran Church in America predecessor churches]] [[Category:Lutheran denominations established in the 19th century]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1890]] [[Category:Lutheran denominations in North America]] [[Category:Finnish-American history]] {{finland-stub}} {{Lutheran-stub}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Louise Allcock | image = File:Louise_Allcock_South_Georgia.jpg | caption = Allcock aboard the [[RRS James Clark Ross]] in [[South Georgia Island|South Georgia]] | fields = Cephalopod ecology | nationality = UK | workplaces = NUI Galway | alma_mater = University of Liverpool | known_for = Editor-in-Chief of the Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society | website = {{URL|nuigalway.ie/our-research/people/natural-sciences/louiseallcock/}} }}
'''Louise Allcock''' is a British researcher, best known for her work on ecology and evolution of the [[cephalopod]]s of the [[Southern Ocean]] and deep sea.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/science/casper-the-ghost-like-octopus-emerges-from-the-deep-1.2661936|title=Casper the ghost-like octopus emerges from the deep|access-date=1 August 2016}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://cosmosmagazine.com/biology/ghost-octopus-believed-be-new-species|title='Ghost octopus' believed to be new species|website=Cosmos Magazine|access-date=1 August 2016}}</ref><ref name=":3" /> She is the editor of the ''[[Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society]]''.
==Early life and education== Allcock graduated in marine biology (with honours) at the [[University of Liverpool]] in 1992. She went on to earn a PhD there in 1998.
==Career and impact== Allcock is the editor of the ''Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society''<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1096-3642|doi=10.1111/(issn)1096-3642}}</ref> and was co-editor of the ''[[Journal of Natural History]]'' from 2007-2015.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Legakis|first=Anastasios|last2=Pafilis|first2=Panagiotis|last3=Parmakelis|first3=Aristidis|date=24 February 2015|title=Editorial|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00222933.2014.987983|journal=Journal of Natural History|volume=49|issue=5–8|pages=255–255|doi=10.1080/00222933.2014.987983|issn=0022-2933}}</ref> She was the president of the Cephalopod International Advisory Council (CIAC) from 2012-2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abdn.ac.uk/CIAC/|title=Cephalopod International Advisory Council - CIAC - squid – octopus – cuttlefish – nautilus|website=abdn.ac.uk|access-date=4 August 2016}}</ref>
Allcock has also worked on gender equality, and is a member of the gender equality task force in Ireland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nuigalway.ie/media/nuigalwayie/content/files/aboutus/Final-Report-Gender-Equality-Task-Force-260516.pdf|title=Report of the gender equality task force, Galway NUI|website=}}</ref> She has highlighted the role and impact of female researchers in cephalopod research.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00222933.2015.1037088|title=The role of female cephalopod researchers: past and present|doi=10.1080/00222933.2015.1037088|volume=49|journal=Journal of Natural History|pages=1235–1266}}</ref>
Allcock's research focuses on the ecology, evolutionary biology and systematics of molluscs.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://news.liverpool.ac.uk/2012/05/09/antarctic-octopuses-10000km-apart-genetically-similar/|title=Antarctic octopuses 10,000km apart "genetically similar" – University of Liverpool News – University of Liverpool|last=Liverpool|first=University of|last2=7zx|first2=L69|access-date=1 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/octopus-chronicles/antarctic-ice-sheet-collapse-recorded-in-octopus-dna/|title=Antarctic Ice Sheet Collapse Recorded in Octopus DNA|last=Harmon|first=Katherine|access-date=1 August 2016}}</ref> Her research expertise also lies in [[benthic ecology]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> She has participated in cruises<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.engineersjournal.ie/2013/06/13/marine-biodiscovery-in-irish-waters/|title=Marine biodiscovery in Irish waters|last=admin|date=13 June 2013|website=Engineers Journal|access-date=1 August 2016}}</ref> in and around the Antarctic and the [[South Atlantic Ocean]], sometimes as leader.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ucc.ie/en/eri/newsandevents/newsarchive/fullstory-340796-en.html|title=News Archive – Environmental Research Institute at University College Cork (UCC)|publisher=[[University College Cork]]|access-date=1 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2013/1119/487553-marine-research/|title=Rare marine habitat found off southwest coast|publisher=Raidió Teilifís Éireann|access-date=1 August 2016}}</ref> As of summer 2016, she is working on taxonomically poor sponges,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/science/deep-sea-sponges-have-healing-qualities-1.676477|title=Deep-sea sponges have healing qualities|access-date=1 August 2016}}</ref> [[cnidarians]] and [[ascidians]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://reellifescience.com/2014/09/03/our-marine-world-by-dr-louise-allcock/|title=Our Marine World, by Dr. Louise Allcock|last=O'Connell|first=Enda|date=3 September 2014|website=ReelLIFE SCIENCE – Schools Video Competition|access-date=1 August 2016}}</ref> Since 2013, Allcock has been a lecturer in zoology at [[NUI Galway]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nuigalway.ie/our-research/people/natural-sciences/louiseallcock/|title=Natural Sciences – NUI Galway|website=nuigalway.ie|access-date=1 August 2016}}</ref> She has also served as Bipolar species co-ordinator for the [[British Antarctic Survey]] from (June 2009 to March 2010), lecturer in Marine Biology, [[Queen's University Belfast]] (September 2002 to March 2008) and Curator of Mollusca, [[National Museums of Scotland]], Edinburgh (July 1998 to August 2002).<ref name=":0" /> On 1 February 2018, Allcock was one of the guests on the [[BBC Radio 4]] discussion programme [[In Our Time (radio series)|In Our Time]], hosted by [[Melvyn Bragg]], about Cephalopods.<ref name = IOT>{{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b09pjgrn | title = In Our Time - Cephalopods | accessdate = 10 February 2018 | publisher = BBC}}</ref>
==Awards and honours== Allcock was the last author on the best scientific paper on cephalopod research 2006–2009 awarded by the Cephalopod International Advisory Council (CIAC).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abdn.ac.uk/CIAC/award.htm|title=Cephalopod International Advisory Council – CIAC – squid – octopus – cuttlefish – nautilus|website=abdn.ac.uk|access-date=1 August 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170127212031/http://www.abdn.ac.uk/CIAC/award.htm|archivedate=27 January 2017|df=}}</ref> The paper on the origin for deep-sea octopuses was also the highlight in the Census of Marine Life press release at the 1st World Congress of Marine Biodiversity, Valencia 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.coml.org/press-releases-2008|title=Press Releases 2008 {{!}} Census of Marine Life|website=www.coml.org|access-date=1 August 2016}}</ref>
== Selected publications == *Strugnell, J.M., Norman, M.D., Vecchione, M., Guzik, M. and Allcock, A.L., 2014. The ink sac clouds octopod evolutionary history. Hydrobiologia, 725(1), pp. 215–235. *{{cite journal | last1 = Allcock | first1 = A.L. | last2 = Lindgren | first2 = A. | last3 = Strugnell | first3 = J.M. | year = 2015 | title = The contribution of molecular data to our understanding of cephalopod evolution and systematics: a review | journal = Journal of Natural History | volume = 49 | issue = 21–24| pages = 1373–1421 | doi=10.1080/00222933.2013.825342}} *Wilson, A.M., Kiriakoulakis, K., Raine, R., Gerritsen, H.D., Blackbird, S., Allcock, A.L. and White, M., 2015. Anthropogenic influence on sediment transport in the Whittard Canyon, NE Atlantic. Marine pollution bulletin, 101(1), pp. 320–329. *Finn, D.I., Clarke, M., Gilbert, M.T.P., Allcock, L., Kampmann, M.L., Schroeder, H., Guerra, A., Norman, M., Winkelmann, J.I., Campos, P.F. and Strugnell, J., 2013. Mitochondrial genome diversity and population structure of. *Allcock, A.L. and Strugnell, J.M., 2012. Southern Ocean diversity: new paradigms from molecular ecology. Trends in ecology & evolution, 27(9), pp. 520–528. * ''Octopus, Squid, and Cuttlefish: A Visual Scientific Guide to the Oceans' Most Advanced Invertebrates'', Roger Hanlon, Mike Vecchione, Louise Allcock, University of Chicago Press, 2018
== References == {{reflist|35em}}
== External links == * [https://scholar.google.com.au/citations?user=Ys-l3hgAAAAJ&hl=en&oi=sra Louise Allcock] on [[Google scholar]] * [http://marinescience.ie/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Dr-A-Louise-Allcock-CV.pdf marinescience.ie/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Dr-A-Louise-Allcock-CV.pdf] * [http://deepseaexperts.org/node/561 deepseaexperts.org/node/561] * [http://nuigalway.ie/our-research/people/natural-sciences/louiseallcock/ nuigalway.ie/our-research/people/natural-sciences/louiseallcock/]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = NSRD | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = group_or_band | alias = Nebijušu Sajūtu Restaurēšanas Darbnīca | origin = [[Riga]], [[Latvia]] | genre = [[Electronic music|Electronic]], [[New wave music|new wave]], [[Experimental music|experimental]] | years_active = 1982–1989 | label = | associated_acts = [[Dzeltenie Pastnieki]]
[[19 Gadi Pirms Sākuma]] | website = | current_members = [[Hārdijs Lediņš]] (deceased)
[[Juris Boiko]] (deceased) | past_members = }} '''NSRD''' or '''Nebijušu Sajūtu Restaurēšanas Darbnīca''' (Latvian for "Workshop for the Restoration of Unfelt Feelings") was a [[Latvia|Latvian]] musical group who also greatly influenced [[New media art|multimedia art]] in their country.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/973024306|title=Workshop for the restoration of unfelt feelings = Nebijušu sajūtu restaurēšanas darbnīca|last=1955-2004|first=Lediņš, Hardijs,|last2=1979-|first2=Astahovska, Ieva,|last3=Māra|first3=Žeikare,|isbn=9789934850998|oclc=973024306}} They played [[Experimental music|experimental]]/[[electronic music]] with influences of [[New wave music|new wave]] and [[New-age music|new-age]]. The band was formed in 1982 by [[Hardijs Lediņš]], architect and DJ, and [[Juris Boiko]], universal artist. In the early years they played electronic avant-garde. They were pioneers of this kind of music in Latvia. Along with their fellow musicians [[Dzeltenie Pastnieki]] (who were more popular than NSRD), they were the first [[New wave music|new wave]] musicians in the [[Latvian SSR]]. Their records were available only on [[magnetic tape]]. As they were so untraditional in the Latvian music scene, they didn't gain a lot of popularity in the 1980s. Nowadays their music is popular among collectors and music fans. ==Discography== *''Invalīdu tramvajs'' (1983) *''Medicīna un māksla'' (1985) *''Kuncendorfs un Osendovskis'' (1984) *''Vējš vītolos'' (music for performance) (1986) *''Faktu vispār nav'' (1987) *''Dr. Enesera binokulāro deju kursi'' (1987) *''30/15'' (1988) *''Neskaties'' (1988) *''Ieva Akurātere un NSRD'' (1989) *''Sarkanie rakordi'' (1989) *''Viegli 3 mana sirds'' (1992, unreleased) *''NSRD labākās dziesmas'' (1982–2002) (2002) *''Dziesmas neuzrakstītai lugai'' (2003, posthumously released in 2006) ==See also== *[[Dzeltenie Pastnieki]] *[[Seque]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nsrd}} [[Category:Latvian electronic music groups]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1982]] [[Category:1982 establishments in the Soviet Union]] == References == {{Europe-band-stub}} {{Latvia-stub}} [[Category:Latvian artists]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox political party |name=New Democracy Electoral Union |native_name=Nova Democracia União Eleitoral |colorcode=Orange |chairman=Quintino de Moreira |foundation=November 2006 (registered 2008) |ideology=[[Big tent]] |position=[[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]] |flag=File:Ndue-angola-symbol.png |country=Angola}} '''New Democracy Electoral Union''' ({{lang-pt|Nova Democracia União Eleitoral}}) is a political coalition in [[Angola]], founded November 18, 2006.<ref name="ao">http://www.nexus.ao/view.cfm?m_id=26390&cat_02=NOTICIAS{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The coalition was registered by the Supreme Court in June 2008, ahead of the [[Angolan legislative election, 2008|September 2008 legislative election]]. Most of the constituents of the coalition had previously been affiliated to another coalition, ''Partidos da Opocição Civil''. Quintino de Moreira is the president of the coalition. He is also the president of the MPDA.<ref name="cmi">{{Cite journal|last=Amundsen|first=Inge|last2=Weimer|first2=Markus|date=2008|title=Opposition Parties and the 2008 Parliamentary Elections in Angola|url=http://www.cmi.no/publications/file/?3103=opposition-parties-and-the-upcoming-2008|journal=CMI Working Paper|language=en|volume=WP 2008:9}}</ref>
Members of New Democracy Electoral Union: *[[Angolan Union for Peace, Democracy and Development]] (UAPDD) *[[Independent National Alliance of Angola]] (ANIA)<ref name="ao"/><ref name="cmi"/> *[[Independent Social Party of Angola]] (PSIA) *[[Liberal Socialist Party (Angola)|Liberal Socialist Party]] (PSL) *[[Movement for the Democracy of Angola]] (MPDA) *[[National Union for Democracy]] (UND)
The coalition received 1.20% of the vote in the 2008 election, winning two out of 220 seats.<ref>[http://www.cne.ao/ National Electoral Commission website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080419071220/http://www.cne.ao/ |date=2008-04-19 }} {{pt icon}}.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Angolan political parties}} [[Category:2006 establishments in Angola]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2006]] [[Category:Political party alliances in Angola]] {{Angola-party-stub}}

revision.text:
<!--... Attention: THIS IS AN OUTLINE
part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{See also|List of Botswana-related topics}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{double image|right|Flag of Botswana.svg|171|Arms of Botswana.svg|148|The [[Flag of Botswana]]|The [[Coat of arms of Botswana]]}} [[File:LocationBotswana.svg|thumb|The location of [[Botswana]]]] [[File:Botswana Map.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable relief map of the [[Republic of Botswana]]]]
The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Botswana:
'''[[Botswana]]''' – a [[Landlocked country|landlocked]] [[List of sovereign states|sovereign country]] located in [[Southern Africa]].<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook>{{cite web|date=3 July 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bc.html|title=Botswana|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=United States [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=23 July 2009}}</ref> Citizens of Botswana are Batswana (singular: Motswana), regardless of ethnicity. Formerly the British [[protectorate]] of [[Bechuanaland Protectorate|Bechuanaland]], Botswana adopted its new name after becoming independent within the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] on 30 September 1966. It is bordered by South Africa to the south and southeast, [[Namibia]] to the west, [[Zambia]] to the north, and [[Zimbabwe]] to the northeast. The economy, closely tied to South Africa's, is dominated by mining (especially diamonds), tourism, and cattle.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
==General reference== [[File:Botswana-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|An enlargeable basic map of [[Botswana]]]] * [[International Phonetic Alphabet|Pronunciation]]: {{IPAc-en|b|ɒ|t|ˈ|s|w|ɑː|n|ə}} * Common English country name: [[Botswana]] * Official English country name: The [[Republic of Botswana]] * Official endonym: [[Lefatshe la Botswana]] * Adjectival: Motswana * [[Demonym]]: [[Batswana]] * Etymology: Land of the Tswana * [[International rankings of Botswana]] * [[ISO country codes]]: BW, BWA, 072 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:BW]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.bw]]
==Geography of Botswana== [[File:Botswana Topography.png|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of [[Botswana]]]]
[[Geography of Botswana]] * Botswana is: a [[landlocked country]] * Location: ** [[Eastern Hemisphere]] and [[Southern Hemisphere]] ** [[Africa]] *** [[Southern Africa]] ** [[Time zone]]: [[Central Africa Time]] ([[UTC+02]]) ** Extreme points of Botswana *** High: [[Otse Hill]] {{convert|1491|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} *** Low: [[Confluence]] of [[Limpopo River]] and [[Shashe River]] {{convert|513|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} ** Land boundaries: 4,013 km ::{{Flag|South Africa}} 1,840 km ::{{Flag|Namibia}} 1,360 km ::{{Flag|Zimbabwe}} 813 km :* Coastline: ''none'' * Population of Botswana: 1,639,833 (2006) - [[List of countries by population|147th most populous country]] * * Area of Botswana: {{convert|600370|km2|sqmi}} - [[List of countries and outlying territories by area|46th largest country]] * [[:commons:Atlas of Botswana|Atlas of Botswana]]
===Environment of Botswana=== [[File:Botswana 24.86445E 22.08661S.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable satellite image of [[Botswana]]]]

====Natural geographic features of Botswana==== * Glaciers in Botswana: none <ref>The only [[List of glaciers in Africa|glaciers in Africa]] are on Mt Kenya (in Kenya), on Kilimanjaro (in Tanzania), and in the Ruwenzori Mountains (which are located in [[Uganda]] and the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]). See [http://iahs.info/redbooks/a126/iahs_126_0197.pdf Proceedings of the Riederalp Workshop, September 1978; Actes de l'Atelier de Riederalp, septembre 1978): IAHS-AISH Publ. no. 126, 1980.]</ref> * Lakes of Botswana ** [[List of dams and reservoirs in Botswana|Dams and reservoirs of Botswana]] * [[List of rivers of Botswana|Rivers of Botswana]] * [[List of World Heritage Sites in Africa#Botswana|World Heritage Sites in Botswana]]: Tsodilo Hills and Okavango Delta

{{Infobox person | name = Robin Niblett | image = Robin Niblett, Director, Chatham House (37656542155) (cropped).jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Niblett in 2017 | birth_date = {{bda|1961|8|20|df=y}} | residence = London, United Kingdom | nationality = British | alma_mater = [[New College, Oxford]] (BA, MPhil and DPhil) | occupation = Director | organization = [[Chatham House]] | box_width = }}
'''Robin Christian Howard Niblett''' [[Order of St Michael and St George|CMG]] (born 20 August 1961)<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title = Birthdays | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | location = | pages = 35 | language = | publisher = Guardian News & Media | date = 20 Aug 2014 | url = | accessdate = 20 Aug 2014}}</ref> is a British specialist in [[international relations]]. He has been the Director of [[Chatham House]] (the Royal Institute of International Affairs) since January 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbetta.com/director/robin-christian-howard-niblett-2/|title=Robin Christian Howard Niblett currently works at Chatham House as a director |website=www.cbetta.com|access-date=22 July 2016}}</ref>
==Education and personal life==
He is the son of Alan and Christine Niblett.<ref>{{cite book|title=Who's Who|date=2016|publisher=A & C Black}}</ref> In 1990, he married Trisha de Borchgrave, with whom he has two daughters.<ref>{{cite book|title=Who's Who|date=2016|publisher=A & C Black}}</ref>
He was educated at [[Cottesmore School]], followed by [[Charterhouse School]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Who's Who|date=2016|publisher=A & C Black}}</ref> He studied at [[New College, Oxford]], and obtained a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in Modern Languages in 1984, followed by [[MPhil]] in 1993 and [[DPhil]] in International Relations in 1995.<ref>{{cite book|title=Who's Who|date=2016|publisher=A & C Black}}</ref> His doctoral [[thesis]] was entitled ''The European Community and the Central European Three, 1989-92 : a study of the Community as an international actor''.
==Early career==
On leaving Oxford, he was a musician 1985–87 (he lists electric guitar among his recreations in ''Who's Who'').<ref>{{cite book|title=Who's Who|date=2016|publisher=A & C Black}}</ref>
==Center for Strategic and International Studies==
He was Resident Associate at the [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]], [[Washington, DC]] 1988–91 and their Europe Representative 1992–97. He was Director, Strategic Planning, 1997–2000; Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer, 2001–06.<ref>[http://www.uscc.gov/bios/2005bios/05_07_21_22/niblett_robin.htm US China Economic Security and Review Commission bio]</ref> During his last two years at CSIS, he also served as Director of the CSIS Europe Program and its Initiative for a Renewed Transatlantic Partnership.<ref>atlantic-community.org, [http://www.atlantic-community.org/index/Global_Must_Read_Article/Dr._Robin_Niblett,_Director_of_Chatham_House Atlantic Faces: Dr Robin Niblett], 3 December 2010</ref>
==Other roles== [[File:Robin Niblett with Carolyn Quinn on BBC R4 PM Programme (4565122413).jpg|thumb|Niblett (left) being interviewed by [[Carolyn Quinn]] in 2010]] Niblett has participated as a panellist at conferences and events around the world<ref>[http://fora.tv/speaker/1166/Dr_Robin_Niblett FORA.tv Speaker - Robin Niblett]</ref><ref>YouTube, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=drC3ULvBhbo Davos Annual Meeting 2010 - Rethinking the Eurozone]</ref> as an expert on [[transatlantic relations]] and European order. He has given evidence to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] Defence Select Committee about the future of [[NATO]] and European defence,<ref>[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmselect/cmdfence/111/7100902.htm House of Commons Select Committee on Defence Minutes of Evidence], 9 October 2007</ref> to the [[House of Commons Foreign Affairs Committee|Foreign Affairs Committee]] about the US-UK relationship<ref>House of Commons Global Security: UK-US Relations - Foreign Affairs Committee, [https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200910/cmselect/cmfaff/114/114we20.htm Written evidence from Dr Robin Niblett, Director, Chatham House]</ref> and the future of UK government policy towards the [[European Union]],<ref>The future of the european Union: UK Government policy, [https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmselect/cmfaff/writev/futunion/m25.htm Written evidence from Dr Robin Niblett, Director, Chatham House]</ref> and to the Select Committee on Soft Power and the UK's Influence.<ref>Chatham House, [http://www.chathamhouse.org/publications/papers/view/198685 Soft Power, Hard Foundations: The Future of the UK’s International Influence], 1 March 2014</ref> He has appeared as an analyst on these topics in major media including the [[BBC]]<ref>BBC News - Today, [http://news.bbc.co.uk/today/hi/today/newsid_8866000/8866256.stm Cameron's 'hard headed' diplomatic strategy], 29 July 2010</ref> and [[CNN]]<ref>CNN, [http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1011/02/ctw.01.html Connect the World], November 2, 2010</ref> and has written and commented for prominent newspapers including the ''[[Financial Times]]'',<ref>''Financial Times'' video, [http://video.ft.com/v/62573457001/Jan-12-Robin-Niblett-on-Europe-s-Russia-policy Jan 12: Robin Niblett on Europe's Russia policy]</ref> ''[[Washington Post]]'',<ref>''The Washington Post'', [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/10/09/AR2009100904381_pf.html Critics Smell Politics in Decision to Honor Obama], October 10, 2009</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]''<ref>''The Guardian'', [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/feb/02/nato-security-online-debate Debating Defence], 2 February 2010</ref> and the ''[[Daily Telegraph]]''.<ref>''The Telegraph'', [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/6206570/Analysis-Barack-Obamas-decision-on-missile-shield-shows-he-is-sticking-to-the-diplomatic-path.html Analysis: Barack Obama's decision on missile shield shows he is sticking to the diplomatic path], 18 September 2009</ref>
He is the editor and contributing author of the book ''America and a Changed World: A Question of Leadership'' and has edited and co-authored books on transatlantic cooperation and European integration. Most recently he authored a chapter in the book ''Influencing Tomorrow: Future Challenges for British Foreign Policy''.<ref>Amazon.co.uk, [https://www.amazon.co.uk/s?_encoding=UTF8&search-alias=books-uk&field-author=Robin%20Niblett Robin Niblett: Books]</ref>
He is a Non-Executive Director of Fidelity European Values Investment Trust since 2010,<ref>Bloomberg Businessweek, [http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=100536749&ticker=FEV:LN&previousCapId=874319&previousTitle=The%20Edinburgh%20Investment%20Trust%20Plc Robin Niblett: Executive Profile & Biography]</ref> member and former Chairman of the [[World Economic Forum|World Economic Forum's]] Global Agenda Council on Europe.<ref>World Economic Forum, [http://www.weforum.org/contributors/robin-niblett Robin Niblett]</ref>
He chaired the [[British Academy]] forum on language needs for UK public policy making and implementation<ref>British Academy, Parker 25 Years On, July 2011 https://www.britac.ac.uk/policy/parker_25_years_on.cfm</ref> and is currently Chairman of the Experts Group for the 2014 NATO Summit.<ref>Press Release, Director of Chatham House to Chair New NATO Group of Policy Experts, http://www.chathamhouse.org/media/news/view/198369</ref>
==Honours==
Niblett was appointed [[Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George]] (CMG) in the 2015 New Year Honours for services to promoting the UK as a global centre for foreign policy.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=61092|supp=y|page=N4|date=31 December 2014}}</ref><ref>[https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/391415/Diplomatic_and_Overseas_NY15_Honours_List.pdf]</ref>

[[Marian Błażej Kruszyłowicz]] |website = [http://www.szczecin.kuria.pl/ Website of the Archdiocese] }} The '''Archdiocese of Szczecin-Kamień''' ({{lang-la|Sedinen(sis) – Caminen(sis)}}) is an [[archdiocese]] located in the cities of [[Szczecin]] and [[Kamień Pomorski]] in [[Poland]]. With 24,3% of its population attending church services weekly or more in 2013 it is the least devoutly religious diocese in Poland. ==History== {{See also|Bishopric of Cammin}} * June 28, 1972: Created as Diocese of Szczecin – Kamień from the [[Diocese of Berlin]] in [[Germany]] * March 25, 1992: Promoted as Metropolitan Archdiocese of Szczecin – Kamień [[Image:KamienPomorski.kosciol.2007.jpg|thumb|200px|left| Co-Cathedral of St John the Baptist in [[Kamień Pomorski]]]] ==Leadership== {{See also|List of bishops of Szczecin-Kamień}} * [[Archbishop]] [[Jerzy Stroba]] (28 Jun 1972 Appointed – 21 Sep 1978 [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Poznań|Appointed, Archbishop of Poznań]]) * [[Archbishop]] [[Kazimierz Jan Majdański]] (1 Mar 1979 Appointed – 25 Mar 1992 Retired) * [[Archbishop]] [[Marian Przykucki]] (25 Mar 1992 Appointed – 1 May 1999 Retired) * [[Archbishop]] [[Zygmunt Kamiński]] (1 May 1999 Appointed – 21 Feb 2009 Retired) * [[Archbishop]] [[Andrzej Dzięga]] (21 Feb 2009 Appointed – ) [[Image:Andrzej Dzięga.jpg|thumb|220px|left| Archbishop Andrzej Dzięga]] ==Suffragan dioceses== * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Koszalin-Kołobrzeg|Koszalin-Kołobrzeg]] * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Zielona Góra-Gorzów|Zielona Góra-Gorzów]] ==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in Poland]] ==Sources== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/szcz0.htm GCatholic.org] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dszcz.html Catholic Hierarchy] * [http://www.szczecin.kuria.pl/ Diocese website] {{coord|53.425000|14.555000|format=dms|display=title|type:landmark}} {{Roman Catholic dioceses in Poland}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Szczecin-Kamien}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Poland]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1972|Szczecin-Kamien Diocese]] {{Poland-stub}} {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}
